Message.Title: Are Techstrategy & Me are the only rational value investors left here?
Message.Msg: The bubblonians keep trying to inflate. Apple at 10 PE. Amazon infinite PE (and maybe 100 forward). There will be a convergence. Such valuation idiocy can only last so long. My HWP spec. buy rec a couple of months ago has worked out-stock up more than 50%.

Topic.Title: Are Techstrategy & Me are the only rational value investors left here?

Message.Msg: Bulls--ask yourself: what stock price would Amazon need to be to match the Apple PE? Can you handle the truth? Lets say Amazon earns $5 next year (most forcasts are lower). A 10 PE yield a price of $50. A 20 PE $100. 30 PE $150. You get the idea.

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: The sell side hasn't done fundamental valuation in forever. They add zero value. Eventually, they'll realize that makes them worthless and expendable, whereas if they were to be intellectually honest and synthesize evolving cost structures and competitive dynamics, there might still be a reason to pay them in the future. By simply projecting off past price action / technicals, they are ensuring secular decline...

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: And it remains a once in a lifetime opportunity for real investors to rotate from a zero net cash, N/A multiple company to one with approaching $150B in cash, huge cash flow and a largely variable cost structure due to its contract manufacturing approach. Increased upside and orders of magnitude less risk. But, those real investors will have to be willing to risk EOQ window dressing knocking AAPL down further and lifting AMZN. In other words, they have to be investors... We'll see if there are any left...

Message.Title: Says Wedbush; ‘Sell Side Are Tools’
Message.Msg: Finally, somebody speaking the truth. I didn't see if he is covering AMZN, but below applies to AMZN, LNKD as well. "Mark is an incorrigible optimist,” said Pachter, continuing, “Netflix did something very clever in Q4. They made $950 million in revenue, and they spent $937 million, so they produced $13 million in profit that took the stock up $5 billion in market cap. Was $13 million really worth $5 billion in stock value? They were expected to lose tons of money, they produced a small profit. Who cares?” " "When presented with the fact that Jefferies & Co.’s Daniel Binder today raised his rating on Best Buy to a Buy, Pachter reflected on the general sell-side research attitude, remarking “Sell-siders are tools,” though he was quick to say that was not a remark about Binder. “If a stock goes up — this is why you gave me grief for my $80 target on NFLX went it was at $300 — the entire sell side adjusts their target to where the stock is going now. I’m in the business of telling you what the stock is worth.” "

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Tech, you seem like a pretty smart guy. Can you see how your statement "If institutional longs were acting like investors..." sounds? Those guys have been making money, you haven't. Your valuation methodology doesn't work with AMZN, can't you see that? It may go to $100 as you predict, but one can predict that ALL stocks will eventually go to zero, unless they're a utility monopoly or something. The timeframe is what matters. I claim AMZN will go over $300 in 2013, that's why I'm still holding some.

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Bruce: We'll see which one proves out. This is an epic bubble enabled by float/option scalping scam. It works until it doesn't and then collapses to valuations supported by fundamentals. That is below $100 in this case. Despite what the VIX and others are signalling, we are headed toward profound market and economic stress for the next few years. The Fed and most of the folks on Wall Street simply are too detached from Main Street to understand the depth and severity of the challenges we face. Good luck. This is a complete trading scam. The question isn't if it will crater. It is when. And those perpetuating it will have to take extraordinary risk over the next 3-6 months to do so...

Message.Msg: The trading volume is so small, which is not seen in months.

Topic.Title: Next quarter results will show millions of losses. This company will never make profit!

Message.Msg: Given the relative valuations of AAPL and AMZN (EV of roughly 2:1, but cash flow more like 20:1), any institutional INVESTOR not rotating hard from AMZN to AAPL is either incompetent or negligent IMHO...

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: I don't think so: I think theo once in a lifetime opportunity to buy AAPL is way past now. Probably in 2009 around 80 and even better in 2003. Not that it can't rally, but when it hit 700, it was valued at twice the next markt cap in the market. That doesn't last. So although it could rally from time to time. , I think it's peak has passed.. Certainly has more value thatn alot of other companies, but if the market peaks on the Fed induced bubble, AAPL will get hit more than just to here.

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: Party: The absence of further losses for those who must be invested will serve as relative gains to peers who are locked into these float jam scams that have no hope of weather true stress. The market volumes will return as soon as we get some "resolution" and the market will tank, just as it tanked AFTER the debt ceiling resolution rather than before. AAPL has over 30% of its market cap in cash. It will still generate tens of billions in cash, even in a recession. In contrast, AMZN could easily fall to 100. In fact, there's no fundamental reason it couldn't go lower. When the market gets hit, certain stocks have been hardened (INTC has 200MM shares short and trades at about 5X ebitda, AAPL's EV is about 5X EBITDA with near record short interest, and so on). Those will hold up fine. Those that got herded into these scams by those that painted the tape will get crushed. Furthermore, if you play out the long term scenarios on how the global system comes back into balance, AAPL will do quite well (although I still think INTC and GOOG are best positioned). Given that we don't know whether the shock will be "deflationary" in the sense of debt writeoffs and collapsing demand (better own companies with lots of cash and cash flow, rather than those whose cash is entirely dependent on growing its negative working capital...) or whether it is from "inflation" via currency devaluation (better own those with huge overseas profits), AAPL will outperform on fundamentals given these prices. Is it a 10X MOMO stock? No. But, none of the others are either. There are -90% returns waiting to happen...

Topic.Title: CNBC...

Message.Msg: All I'm saying is if you have to be invested in the market (because long only funds do not get paid to sit on cash) and you have the opportunity to exchange 1.5 shares of Amazon for each share of AAPL, a wise institutional long should do that as aggressively as possibly before the entire market takes its plunge (the same logic applies to the other newer sources of capital being used to perpetuate this scam). Once the market starts to break, that ratio will rapidly move to 2.5 to 1 or more.... FWIW, cash too will lose value. That's the whole idea of financial repression...

Message.Title: FPE
Message.Msg: The FPE is 76 and that's based on analyst estimates of $0.09 next quarter followed by 0.22, 1.47, and 3.61 !!! The previous quarters' actuals that match these same quarters were 0.28, .01. -0.60 and 0.21. The requirements for gainful employment as an AMZN analyst apparently include healthy lungs, to continuously blow the bubble bigger.
